title: Overview
description: Welcome to Longitudinal.dev, an open-source platform focused on managing, analyzing, and visualizing longitudinal data. Whether you're a beginner exploring longitudinal data science or an experienced researcher, this platform offers the tools and resources you need to uncover insights and make data-driven decisions.

children.value: Longitudinal data science involves the analysis of data collected repeatedly over time. Unlike cross-sectional analysis, which provides a snapshot at a single point, longitudinal studies allow you to track changes, trends, and patterns across multiple timepoints. This approach is essential in areas like public health, social sciences, education, and behavioral research.
Core Components of Longitudinal Data Science
Accurately gathering and preparing data over time.
Visualizing and detecting trends and patterns.
Applying models like mixed-effects or growth curve modeling to assess relationships over time.
Leveraging past data to predict future trends.
Drawing actionable insights supported by visualizations and documentation.
Getting Started with Longitudinal Data Science
To start your journey, focus on learning key programming languages, especially
A versatile language with a vast ecosystem, including libraries like
A domain-specific language tailored for statistical analysis, with packages like
Clean, transform, and organize your data effectively.
Build a strong foundation in statistics, including regression, hypothesis testing, and modeling.
Generate insightful plots and charts that reveal trends over time.
Apply time series models, growth curves, and machine learning techniques to longitudinal data.
Our platform offers a comprehensive suite of features designed for every stage of longitudinal data analysis:
Easily import, clean, and organize your datasets with intuitive data wrangling tools.
Create dynamic visualizations that reveal trends and patterns across timepoints, with customization options for line plots, heatmaps, and more.
Access built-in tools for complex analyses like mixed-effects models, latent growth modeling, and time series analysis.
Seamlessly share datasets, scripts, and visualizations with team members, supported by version control and transparent workflows.
Automate repetitive tasks like data cleaning, model fitting, and reporting with reusable scripts and workflows.
Your data is protected with industry-standard security practices, ensuring compliance with key regulations.
Effortlessly handle large-scale longitudinal datasets, whether working with hundreds or thousands of participants, without compromising performance.
Whether you‚Äôre analyzing clinical trial data, monitoring educational outcomes, or studying behavioral patterns,
is designed to help you succeed in longitudinal data science.

children.value: Autoregressive Cross-Lagged (ARCL) Models are statistical techniques used in longitudinal data analysis to examine the reciprocal relationships between two or more variables over time while accounting for their stability. These models combine autoregressive paths, which capture the stability of each variable by modeling its effect on itself at subsequent time points, with cross-lagged paths, which represent the influence of one variable on another at later time points. By including both types of paths, ARCL models allow researchers to assess the directionality and strength of associations between variables over time.

In an ARCL model, the autoregressive paths control for prior levels of each variable, isolating the unique effect that one variable has on another beyond their inherent stability. This is particularly useful when exploring dynamic processes where variables may influence each other reciprocally, such as the relationship between academic achievement and self-esteem over time. By modeling these reciprocal effects, researchers can gain insights into potential causal mechanisms and temporal precedence in the relationships among variables.

ARCL models are widely used in psychology, education, and social sciences to explore developmental processes and the interplay between variables across multiple time points. They offer a comprehensive framework for understanding how variables influence each other over time, accounting for both their stability and cross-influences, thereby providing a deeper understanding of the complex dynamics present in longitudinal data.
ü§î When to Use Autoregressive Cross-Lagged Models?
You might consider using ARCL models when:
You have two or more variables measured repeatedly over time.
You are interested in understanding reciprocal or bidirectional relationships between variables.
You want to assess how one variable influences another at future time points.
üöÄ Getting Started with Autoregressive Cross-Lagged Models
In this tutorial, we will guide you through a simple example of how to apply ARCL models in R. By the end of this tutorial, you will:
Understand the basic concept of ARCL models.
Fit an ARCL model to longitudinal data using R.
Interpret the results and visualize the cross-lagged relationships.
We will use a dataset with two variables,
, measured over three time points. The dataset includes:
: A unique identifier for each individual.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = 1:10,
  A_T1 = rnorm(10, mean = 50, sd = 10),
  A_T2 = rnorm(10, mean = 52, sd = 10),
  A_T3 = rnorm(10, mean = 54, sd = 10),
  B_T1 = rnorm(10, mean = 30, sd = 5),
  B_T2 = rnorm(10, mean = 31, sd = 5),
  B_T3 = rnorm(10, mean = 32, sd = 5)
)

# View the first few rows of the dataset
head(data)

children.value: # View the first few rows of the dataset
Fitting an Autoregressive Cross-Lagged Model in R
package to specify and fit the ARCL model. In this example, we estimate autoregressive paths for

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Install and load necessary library
if (!require(lavaan)) install.packages("lavaan")
library(lavaan)

# Define the ARCL model
arcl_model <- '
  # Autoregressive paths
  A_T2 ~ A_T1
  A_T3 ~ A_T2
  B_T2 ~ B_T1
  B_T3 ~ B_T2

  # Cross-lagged paths
  B_T2 ~ A_T1
  B_T3 ~ A_T2
  A_T2 ~ B_T1
  A_T3 ~ B_T2
'

# Fit the ARCL model
fit <- sem(arcl_model, data = data)

# Display model summary
summary(fit, fit.measures = TRUE)

children.value: The autoregressive paths represent the stability of each variable over time, while the cross-lagged paths capture how one variable influences the other at later time points. A significant cross-lagged path suggests that changes in one variable predict changes in the other.
Visualizing the estimated relationships can help illustrate how the variables influence each other across time points.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 library for visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Plot the time-series data for Variable A and Variable B
data_long <- reshape2::melt(data, id.vars = "SubjectID", variable.name = "Time_Variable", value.name = "Score")
data_long$Time <- as.numeric(sub(".*_(T)", "", data_long$Time_Variable))
data_long$Variable <- sub("_T.*", "", data_long$Time_Variable)

ggplot(data_long, aes(x = Time, y = Score, color = Variable)) +
  geom_line(aes(group = interaction(SubjectID, Variable))) +
  facet_wrap(~SubjectID) +
  labs(
    title = "Time-Series Data for Variable A and Variable B",
    x = "Time",
    y = "Score"
  )

children.value: # Plot the time-series data for Variable A and Variable B
Time-Series Data for Variable A and Variable B
Try adding more time points or additional variables to the ARCL model and explore how the relationships change.

You‚Äôve now learned how to apply autoregressive cross-lagged models to examine bidirectional relationships over time. ARCL models provide insights into how variables influence each other across different time points, helping you better understand dynamic systems.

children.value: Cross-Lagged Panel Models (CLPM) are a type of structural equation model used in longitudinal research to examine the reciprocal relationships between two or more variables measured at multiple time points. CLPM incorporate both autoregressive paths, which model the stability of each variable over time, and cross-lagged paths, which represent the influence of one variable on another at subsequent time points. By simultaneously estimating these paths, CLPM help disentangle the temporal ordering and potential causal relationships between variables.

In a CLPM, the autoregressive paths control for prior levels of each variable, allowing the cross-lagged paths to reflect the unique effect of one variable on changes in another over time. This enables researchers to assess whether changes in one variable precede and potentially contribute to changes in another, providing insights into possible directional influences. CLPM are particularly useful for testing theories about the dynamic interplay between variables and for exploring how relationships evolve over time.

These models are widely used in fields such as psychology, education, and social sciences to investigate developmental processes, behavioral interactions, and other phenomena where understanding the direction and strength of relationships over time is important. By accounting for both stability and cross-lagged effects, Cross-Lagged Panel Models offer a robust framework for analyzing longitudinal data and for making inferences about the potential causal pathways between variables.
ü§î When to Use Cross-Lagged Panel Models?
You have at least two variables measured at multiple time points.
You are interested in examining the reciprocal relationships between these variables over time.
You want to assess both the stability of the variables and the cross-lagged effects between them.
üöÄ Getting Started with Cross-Lagged Panel Models
In this tutorial, you will learn how to:
Understand the structure of a cross-lagged panel model.
Fit a CLPM using R with two variables measured at two time points.
Interpret the results, including autoregressive and cross-lagged effects.

We will generate a dataset where two variables (e.g., academic performance and motivation) are measured at two time points. This allows us to examine both the stability of each variable and their reciprocal relationships over time.
: A unique identifier for each participant.
: The first variable measured at time 1 (e.g., academic performance).
: The first variable measured at time 2.
: The second variable measured at time 1 (e.g., motivation).
: The second variable measured at time 2.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = 1:20,
  Var1_T1 = rnorm(20, mean = 50, sd = 10),
  Var1_T2 = rnorm(20, mean = 52, sd = 10),
  Var2_T1 = rnorm(20, mean = 30, sd = 5),
  Var2_T2 = rnorm(20, mean = 32, sd = 5)
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: Fitting a Cross-Lagged Panel Model in R

package to fit a cross-lagged panel model. This model will include both autoregressive paths (the effect of each variable on itself across time) and cross-lagged paths (the effect of each variable on the other variable across time).

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Install and load necessary library
if (!require(lavaan)) install.packages("lavaan")
library(lavaan)

# Define the CLPM
clpm_model <- '
  # Autoregressive paths
  Var1_T2 ~ Var1_T1
  Var2_T2 ~ Var2_T1

  # Cross-lagged paths
  Var2_T2 ~ Var1_T1
  Var1_T2 ~ Var2_T1
'

# Fit the CLPM
fit <- sem(clpm_model, data = data)

# Display the model summary
summary(fit, fit.measures = TRUE)

children.value: The autoregressive paths estimate the stability of each variable over time, while the cross-lagged paths provide information about the reciprocal effects between the two variables. For example, a significant cross-lagged path from Var1_T1 to Var2_T2 would suggest that academic performance at time 1 influences motivation at time 2.
We can plot the results to visualize the relationships between the variables over time.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 for visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Reshape the data for visualization
data_long <- reshape2::melt(data, id.vars = "SubjectID", variable.name = "Variable", value.name = "Score")
data_long$Time <- as.numeric(sub(".*_(T)", "", data_long$Variable))
data_long$Variable <- sub("_T.*", "", data_long$Variable)

# Plot the trajectories
ggplot(data_long, aes(x = Time, y = Score, color = Variable)) +
  geom_line(aes(group = interaction(SubjectID, Variable))) +
  labs(
    title = "Cross-Lagged Panel Model: Variable Trajectories",
    x = "Time",
    y = "Score"
  )

children.value: Experiment with adding more time points or additional variables to the model. Explore how different cross-lagged effects influence the relationship between variables over time.

Cross-lagged panel models are a powerful tool for examining reciprocal relationships between variables over time. They allow you to assess both the stability of each variable and how they dynamically influence each other. This approach is particularly useful in longitudinal research where understanding these interactions is crucial.
üîó Further Resources for Learning About Cross-Lagged Panel Models
"Principles and Practice of Structural Equation Modeling"
by Rex B. Kline: A great resource for understanding the theory and application of cross-lagged panel models.
by Todd Little: Another excellent resource on structural equation modeling, including CLPMs.
Cross-Lagged Panel Models in R by IDRE at UCLA
: A detailed guide on how to fit CLPMs in R.

children.value: Latent Change Score Models (LCSM) are extensions of traditional latent growth models, designed to explicitly model the change between consecutive time points. By focusing on the latent change scores, LCSM allows researchers to assess how much individuals change over time and to explore the factors that drive this change. Unlike traditional growth models that focus on modeling trajectories using slopes and intercepts, LCSMs directly capture the change between successive time points. This approach models the change itself as a latent variable, capturing individual differences in growth rates and providing insights into the dynamics of the change process. By directly modeling these latent changes, LCSM enables the examination of relationships between changes in different variables over time.

In LCSMs, the change between measurements is treated as a latent construct, enabling the separation of true change from measurement error. This approach allows researchers to model the factors influencing change scores, such as the effect of time-varying covariates, and to examine individual differences in change processes. By specifying the relationships between initial levels, change scores, and covariates, LCSMs provide a flexible framework for testing hypotheses about the mechanisms driving change over time.

Latent Change Score Models are particularly useful when the interest lies in understanding the dynamics of change itself rather than just the overall trajectory. They can accommodate non-linear patterns of change and are capable of modeling reciprocal effects between variables over time. This makes LCSMs a powerful tool in fields like psychology, education, and health sciences, where capturing the complexity of developmental processes is essential.
ü§î When to Use Latent Change Score Models?
You should consider using LCSM when:
You are interested in modeling changes between consecutive time points.
You want to understand the factors that influence changes in your outcome variable.
You are analyzing longitudinal data and want to focus explicitly on change processes.
üöÄ Getting Started with Latent Change Score Models
In this tutorial, you will learn how to:
Understand the structure of a Latent Change Score Model.
Fit an LCSM in R using example data.
Interpret the results to understand the change processes and individual differences in change.
We will use a dataset where the outcome variable is measured at three time points. LCSM will help us model the latent change between consecutive time points and explore what influences these changes.
: A unique identifier for each individual.
: The outcome variable measured at time 1.
: The outcome variable measured at time 2.
: The outcome variable measured at time 3.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = 1:100,
  Outcome_T1 = rnorm(100, mean = 50, sd = 10),
  Outcome_T2 = rnorm(100, mean = 52, sd = 10),
  Outcome_T3 = rnorm(100, mean = 54, sd = 10)
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: Fitting a Latent Change Score Model in R
package in R to fit an LCSM. The model will estimate the change scores between consecutive time points as latent variables.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Install and load necessary library
if (!require(lavaan)) install.packages("lavaan")
library(lavaan)

# Define the LCSM model
lcsm_model <- '
  # Latent change score between time 1 and time 2
  dT2 =~ 1*Outcome_T2
  Outcome_T2 ~ 1*Outcome_T1

  # Latent change score between time 2 and time 3
  dT3 =~ 1*Outcome_T3
  Outcome_T3 ~ 1*Outcome_T2
'

# Fit the LCSM
fit <- lavaan::sem(lcsm_model, data = data)

# Display the model summary
summary(fit, fit.measures = TRUE)

children.value: # Latent change score between time 1 and time 2
# Latent change score between time 2 and time 3

The latent change scores represent the difference between the outcome at consecutive time points. By examining these latent change variables, we can understand how much individuals change over time and explore the factors that influence this change.
We can plot the observed data and the estimated latent change scores to visualize the changes over time.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 for visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Reshape data for visualization
data_long <- reshape2::melt(data, id.vars = "SubjectID", variable.name = "Time", value.name = "Outcome")
data_long$Time <- as.numeric(sub("Outcome_T", "", data_long$Time))

# Plot individual trajectories and change scores
ggplot(data_long, aes(x = Time, y = Outcome, group = SubjectID)) +
  geom_line(alpha = 0.4) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "line", color = "blue", size = 1.2) +
  labs(
    title = "Latent Change Score Model: Individual Trajectories and Change Scores",
    x = "Time",
    y = "Outcome"
  )

children.value: # Plot individual trajectories and change scores
Latent Change Score Model: Individual Trajectories and Change Scores

Experiment with adding predictors of the change scores (e.g., covariates that may influence the rate of change). You can also explore more complex change processes by including additional time points or modeling non-linear change.

Latent Change Score Models provide a flexible approach for modeling change over time. By focusing on the latent change process, LCSM allows researchers to explore what drives individual differences in change and how these changes unfold across time.
üîó Further Resources for Learning About Latent Change Score Models
"Latent Change Score Models in Longitudinal Research"
by John McArdle: A comprehensive guide to understanding LCSM and its applications in longitudinal research.
by Judith Singer: A useful resource for learning about latent change and growth models.
Latent Change Score Models in R by IDRE at UCLA
: A detailed guide to fitting LCSM in R.

children.value: Latent Transition Analysis (LTA) is a statistical technique used to model changes in unobserved categorical states over time within a longitudinal framework. As an extension of latent class analysis (LCA), LTA identifies latent classes at each time point and estimates the probabilities of individuals transitioning between these classes across multiple time points. This approach allows researchers to examine patterns of change in categorical latent variables, such as behavioral or psychological states, and to assess how covariates may influence these transitions.

In LTA, individuals are assumed to belong to latent classes that represent unobserved subgroups within the population. By modeling the probabilities of transitioning from one latent class to another over time, LTA captures both the stability and change in these unobserved states. This provides insights into the dynamics of latent constructs, such as how certain behaviors may emerge, persist, or dissipate over time.

LTA is particularly useful where understanding the progression of categorical states is essential. By incorporating covariates, researchers can explore factors that predict class membership and transition probabilities, enabling a deeper understanding of the mechanisms underlying change. Overall, Latent Transition Analysis offers a powerful framework for analyzing longitudinal categorical data, revealing complex patterns of development and change within populations.
ü§î When to Use Latent Transition Analysis?
You have longitudinal data and want to identify subgroups that change over time.
You are interested in understanding how individuals transition between different latent classes (e.g., risk levels, behavioral profiles) over time.
You want to explore how covariates influence transitions between these latent states.
üöÄ Getting Started with Latent Transition Analysis
In this tutorial, we will guide you through:
Understanding the structure of a Latent Transition Analysis.
Fitting an LTA in R using a simple dataset.
Interpreting the results to understand transitions between latent classes.
We will work with a dataset where we observe latent class membership at two time points. LTA will help us identify latent classes at each time point and model the transitions between them.
: A unique identifier for each individual.
: Latent class membership at time point 1.
: Latent class membership at time point 2.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = 1:100,
  Class_T1 = sample(1:2, 100, replace = TRUE),
  Class_T2 = sample(1:2, 100, replace = TRUE)
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: Fitting a Latent Transition Analysis in R
package in R to fit an LTA. This package allows us to estimate latent class membership and transitions between classes.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Install and load necessary library
if (!require(poLCA)) install.packages("poLCA")
library(poLCA)

# Define the LTA model
lta_model <- "
  # Latent classes at time point 1
  Class_T1 =~ 1*Class_T1
  
  # Latent classes at time point 2
  Class_T2 =~ 1*Class_T2

  # Transitions between classes
  Class_T2 ~ Class_T1
"

# Fit the LTA using poLCA
fit <- poLCA(lta_model, data)

# Display model summary
summary(fit)

children.value: The output from the LTA provides the probabilities of transitioning between latent classes from one time point to the next. It also estimates the overall class membership probabilities at each time point.
We can visualize the transitions between latent classes using a Sankey diagram to illustrate how individuals move between classes over time.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 for visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Create a simple transition matrix for plotting
transition_matrix <- table(data$Class_T1, data$Class_T2)

# Plot the transitions using a heatmap
ggplot(as.data.frame(transition_matrix), aes(x = Var1, y = Var2, fill = Freq)) +
  geom_tile() +
  labs(
    title = "Latent Class Transitions",
    x = "Class at Time 1",
    y = "Class at Time 2",
    fill = "Count"
  )

children.value: # Create a simple transition matrix for plotting
# Plot the transitions using a heatmap

Experiment with adding covariates to the model to see how factors like age or education influence transitions between latent classes. You can also explore adding more time points to track transitions over a longer period.

Latent Transition Analysis is a powerful tool for modeling changes in latent class membership over time. By identifying transitions between latent states, LTA provides valuable insights into how individuals evolve and how external factors influence their movement between classes.
üîó Further Resources for Learning About Latent Transition Analysis
by Jacques Hagenaars: A comprehensive guide to LTA and its applications in longitudinal research.
by Linda Muth√©n: An excellent resource for understanding and applying LTA models.
Latent Transition Analysis in R by IDRE at UCLA
: A practical guide for fitting LTA in R.

children.value: Residualized Change Scores are a statistical method used in longitudinal data analysis to measure change over time while controlling for baseline levels. This approach involves regressing a follow-up score (e.g., Time 2) on its baseline score (e.g., Time 1) and extracting the residuals from this regression. These residuals represent the portion of the follow-up score that is not explained by the baseline score, effectively isolating the unique variance in the outcome at the later time point after accounting for initial levels.

By controlling for individual differences at baseline, residualized change scores allow researchers to obtain a more precise estimate of the relationship between predictors and changes in the outcome variable. This method helps adjust for regression to the mean and reduces potential biases that can occur when using simple difference scores. Residualized change scores are particularly useful when the interest lies in understanding how predictors are associated with changes over time rather than with the outcome at a single time point.

This approach is straightforward to implement and interpret, making it valuable where identifying factors that contribute to change is essential. By focusing on the unexplained variance in the follow-up measure, residualized change scores provide insights into the mechanisms underlying development, progression, or the effects of interventions over time.
You should consider using residualized change scores in the following scenarios:
You are interested in understanding the change in an outcome variable while accounting for baseline levels.
You want to control for individual differences at baseline to better assess the effect of predictors on the change over time.
You are working with longitudinal data where a single predictor variable measured at Time 1 may influence a subsequent outcome at Time 2, and you wish to isolate its unique effect on the change.
üöÄ Getting Started with Residualized Change Scores
In this tutorial, we will introduce the concept of residualized change scores and walk through an example using a simple dataset. By the end of this tutorial, you will be able to:
Understand the basic structure and purpose of residualized change scores.
Calculate residualized change scores using linear regression in R.
Interpret the results of a residualized change score analysis.
For this tutorial, we will use a small dataset with two time points (Time 1 and Time 2) and a predictor variable:

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = 1:10,
  Time1 = rnorm(10, mean = 50, sd = 10),
  Time2 = rnorm(10, mean = 55, sd = 10),
  Predictor = rbinom(10, 1, 0.5)
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: The next step is to calculate the residualized change scores by regressing the Time 2 scores on the Time 1 scores and extracting the residuals.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Fit a linear model regressing Time 2 scores on Time 1 scores
residual_model <- lm(Time2 ~ Time1, data = data)

# Extract residuals (the residualized change scores)
data$residualized_change <- residuals(residual_model)

# View the first few rows with residualized change scores
head(data)

children.value: # Fit a linear model regressing Time 2 scores on Time 1 scores
# View the first few rows with residualized change scores
These residuals represent the amount of change in Time 2 that is not explained by Time 1, effectively isolating the change in the outcome.
Fitting a Model with Residualized Change Scores
Once you have the residualized change scores, you can use them as the dependent variable in a new regression model to test the effect of a predictor variable (e.g., treatment condition).

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Fit a regression model with the residualized change scores as the outcome
final_model <- lm(residualized_change ~ Predictor, data = data)

# Display the model summary
summary(final_model)

children.value: # Fit a regression model with the residualized change scores as the outcome

In the output, the coefficient for the predictor variable represents its effect on the change in the outcome, after accounting for the baseline score. This allows you to assess the unique effect of the predictor on change over time.
Visualizing the residualized change scores can help you better understand how different subjects or groups changed over time.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 library
library(ggplot2)

# Plot residualized change scores by predictor group
ggplot(data, aes(x = Predictor, y = residualized_change)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(
    title = "Residualized Change Scores by Predictor Group",
    x = "Predictor Group",
    y = "Residualized Change"
  )

children.value: # Plot residualized change scores by predictor group
Residualized Change Scores by Predictor Group
Explore further by testing residualized change scores with more complex datasets, such as those with additional covariates or multiple time points. Experiment in our
to practice calculating and interpreting residualized change scores.

Residualized change scores are just one approach to analyzing change over time. Consider exploring other methods like latent growth curve models (LGCM), latent change score models, or difference scores to compare their effectiveness in your data.

Congratulations on completing this tutorial! You‚Äôve learned how to calculate and interpret residualized change scores, apply them to longitudinal data, and assess how a predictor influences change over time. Keep experimenting and building your knowledge in longitudinal data analysis!
üîó Further Resources for Learning About Residualized Change Scores
For further reading and resources on residualized change scores and longitudinal data analysis:
by Singer & Willett: A great introduction to methods for studying change, including residualized change scores.
by Jason Newsom: A helpful resource for understanding various techniques for analyzing longitudinal data.
Residualized Change Scores in R by IDRE at UCLA
: A step-by-step guide on calculating and interpreting residualized change scores in R.
: A course that covers various methods for analyzing longitudinal data, including residualized change scores.
: A video tutorial explaining the concept and application of residualized change scores.
These resources will help you gain a deeper understanding of residualized change scores and their application to longitudinal data.

children.value: Hierarchical Linear Modeling (HLM), also known as multilevel modeling or mixed-effects modeling, is a statistical technique used to analyze data that have a nested or hierarchical structure. In many research contexts, data are collected at multiple levels‚Äîfor example, students nested within classrooms, employees within organizations, or repeated measurements within individuals over time. Traditional linear regression methods may not adequately account for the interdependencies among observations within these nested structures, potentially leading to biased estimates and incorrect inferences.

HLM addresses this issue by allowing for the simultaneous examination of relationships at different levels of analysis. It does this by specifying models that include both fixed effects, which are consistent across units, and random effects, which vary at one or more levels of the hierarchy. For instance, an HLM can model how individual-level predictors influence outcomes while also accounting for group-level influences, such as classroom characteristics affecting student performance. This approach enables researchers to partition the variance in the outcome variable into components attributable to different levels, providing a more accurate and nuanced understanding of the data.

By incorporating random effects, HLM can model variability both within and between groups, offering insights into how context influences individual outcomes. The flexibility of HLM makes it suitable for a wide range of applications, including longitudinal studies where measurements are nested within individuals over time. Overall, Hierarchical Linear Modeling provides a robust framework for analyzing complex data structures, enhancing the ability to draw meaningful conclusions from nested or clustered data.
ü§î When to Use Hierarchical Linear Modeling?
You have nested data, such as students within schools or patients within hospitals.
You want to model both individual- and group-level effects simultaneously.
You need to account for the non-independence of observations within groups.
üöÄ Getting Started with Hierarchical Linear Modeling
In this tutorial, we will walk through a simple example of fitting a hierarchical linear model in R. By the end of this tutorial, you will:
Fit a two-level hierarchical model using R.
Interpret the results, including fixed and random effects.

We will create a simple dataset where students (level 1) are nested within schools (level 2). Each student has an outcome score (e.g., test score), and each school has a group-level variable (e.g., school resources).
: A unique identifier for each student.
: A unique identifier for each school.
: A group-level predictor for schools (e.g., resources).

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  StudentID = 1:100,
  SchoolID = rep(1:10, each = 10),
  Score = rnorm(100, mean = 75, sd = 10),
  SchoolResources = rep(rnorm(10, mean = 50, sd = 5), each = 10)
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: Fitting a Two-Level Hierarchical Linear Model in R
package to fit a two-level hierarchical model, where we predict student test scores based on both individual- and school-level factors.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load necessary library
if (!require(lme4)) install.packages("lme4")
library(lme4)

# Fit a two-level hierarchical model
hlm_model <- lmer(Score ~ SchoolResources + (1 | SchoolID), data = data)

# Display the model summary
summary(hlm_model)

children.value: In the output, the fixed effects estimate the effect of school resources on student test scores, while the random effects estimate the variation between schools. The random intercepts capture differences in average test scores across schools.
You can extend the model by allowing the effect of school resources to vary across schools, adding random slopes to the model.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Fit a random slope model
hlm_model_slopes <- lmer(Score ~ SchoolResources + (SchoolResources | SchoolID), data = data)

# Display the model summary
summary(hlm_model_slopes)

children.value: Plotting the random intercepts and slopes helps visualize the variation across groups (schools).

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 for visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Create a random intercepts plot
ggplot(data, aes(x = SchoolResources, y = Score, color = factor(SchoolID))) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  labs(
    title = "Random Intercepts and Slopes by School",
    x = "School Resources",
    y = "Test Score",
    color = "School ID"
  )

children.value: Random Intercepts and Slopes by School
Try modifying the model by adding student-level predictors (e.g., student socioeconomic status) or experimenting with different correlation structures to see how they influence the results.

You‚Äôve now learned the basics of hierarchical linear modeling, a powerful technique for analyzing nested data. HLM allows you to account for both individual- and group-level effects, providing a more nuanced understanding of your data.
üîó Further Resources for Learning About Hierarchical Linear Modeling
"Multilevel and Longitudinal Modeling with IBM SPSS"
by Heck, Thomas, and Tabata: A great introduction to multilevel modeling.
by Raudenbush and Bryk: A classic text on HLM, covering both theory and applications.
HLM in R by IDRE at UCLA
: A step-by-step guide to fitting multilevel models in R.

children.value: Linear Mixed-Effects Models, also known as linear mixed models (LMMs), are versatile statistical tools used to analyze data that involve both fixed effects and random effects. Fixed effects represent population-wide trends consistent across all observations, while random effects account for individual or group-level variability. LMMs are particularly useful for handling data with hierarchical or nested structures, such as measurements nested within individuals or individuals nested within groups. In situations where observations are correlated due to these nested structures, traditional linear regression models may not adequately account for the dependency among observations, potentially leading to biased estimates and invalid inferences.

In longitudinal analyses, LMMs are often preferred because they allow for individual-specific baselines and rates of change by incorporating random intercepts and slopes. This flexibility makes LMMs ideal for capturing both overall trends and individual variations, offering a more nuanced understanding of the data compared to simpler regression models. For example, in a study measuring students‚Äô academic performance over time, a linear mixed-effects model can include fixed effects for overall trends and random effects to account for individual differences in intercepts and slopes, modeling both the average effect and the individual deviations from that average. By partitioning the variance into components attributable to fixed and random effects, LMMs provide a flexible framework for analyzing complex data structures. They can handle unbalanced data, missing values, and varying numbers of observations, making them suitable for longitudinal studies and repeated measures designs.
ü§î When to Use Linear Mixed Models (LMMs)?
You should consider using LMMs in the following scenarios:
You want to understand both overall population trends and individual variations over time.
Your outcome variable is measured repeatedly for the same subjects across multiple time points.
You have data with a hierarchical or nested data and need to account for correlated observations.
üöÄ Getting Started with Longitudinal Linear Mixed Models
In this tutorial, we will introduce the concept of linear mixed-effects models (LMMs) and guide you through a simple example using a small dataset. By the end of this tutorial, you will be able to:
Understand the basic structure of linear mixed models.
Fit a longitudinal linear mixed model using example data in R.
Interpret the results of the LMM analysis.
For this tutorial, we will use a simple dataset containing the following information for a group of individuals:
Outcome variable (e.g., a measure of cognitive performance)

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = rep(1:5, each = 4),
  Time = rep(0:3, times = 5),
  Outcome = c(100, 105, 110, 115, 95, 100, 105, 110, 90, 95, 100, 105, 85, 90, 95, 100, 80, 85, 90, 95)
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: Fitting Linear Mixed-Effects Models in R
package in R to fit a
, where each individual has their own baseline (intercept).

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load necessary libraries
library(lme4)

# Fit a random intercept model
model1 <- lmer(Outcome ~ Time + (1 | SubjectID), data = data)

# Display model summary to examine fixed and random effects
summary(model1)

children.value: # Display model summary to examine fixed and random effects

In the output, the fixed effects provide the population-wide average relationship between the predictors (e.g., age) and the response variable (e.g., height). The random effects show how much individual subjects deviate from this average.
, meaning that individuals can differ not only in their intercepts (baselines) but also in their rate of change over time.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load necessary libraries
library(lme4)

# Fit a random slope model
model2 <- lmer(Outcome ~ Time + (Time | SubjectID), data = data)

# Display model summary to examine fixed and random effects
summary(model2)

children.value: # Display model summary to examine fixed and random effects
Now, each child has their own growth rate!
Once we‚Äôve fitted our models, we need to assess how well they fit the data.
Model Fit: AIC, BIC, and Likelihood Ratio Tests
One way to assess model fit is by comparing models using
(Bayesian Information Criterion). A lower AIC or BIC indicates a better model fit.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Comparing model fit
AIC(model1, model2)

children.value: Check the residuals to ensure that the assumptions of normality and homoscedasticity hold.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Plot residuals
plot(model2)

children.value: If the residuals are roughly normally distributed and homoscedastic, the model is well-fitted.
Visualizing both the raw data and the fitted model is key for understanding your results.
to visualize the data points and individual growth trajectories.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 library
library(ggplot2)

# Plot raw data
ggplot(data, aes(x = Time, y = Outcome, color = factor(SubjectID))) +
    geom_point() +
    geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
    labs(
        title = "Raw Data: Individual Growth Trajectories",
        x = "Time (years)",
        y = "Outcome",
        color = "Subject ID"
    )

children.value: Next, plot the predicted growth curves for each individual based on the model:

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Add predicted values to the dataset
data$pred <- predict(model2)

# Plot predicted values
ggplot(data, aes(x = Time, y = pred, color = factor(SubjectID))) +
    geom_line() +
    labs(
        title = "Predicted Growth Curves by Subject",
        x = "Time (years)",
        y = "Predicted Outcome",
        color = "Subject ID"
    )

children.value: # Add predicted values to the dataset

We encourage you to explore real-world examples and experiment with models in our interactive sandbox. You can practice fitting models like random intercept models, random slope models, and compare their AIC values through the
Congratulations on completing this tutorial! You‚Äôve learned how to fit and interpret linear mixed-effects models for longitudinal data, assess model fit, and visualize the results.

For more advanced topics, continue exploring nested models, GLMMs, and more complex structures as you build confidence with LMMs. Keep practicing, and don‚Äôt hesitate to refer back to this guide as you progress.
üîó Further Resources for Learning About Linear Mixed Models
If you're looking to deepen your understanding of Linear Mixed Models (LMMs) and explore more advanced topics, here are some excellent resources:
by Douglas Bates: A comprehensive guide on LMMs using the
by Garrett Fitzmaurice: An excellent resource for learning about mixed models in the context of longitudinal data.
package, which is widely used for fitting linear mixed models in R.
Mixed Models in R by UCLA
: A beginner-friendly online tutorial that provides step-by-step guidance on how to fit mixed models in R.
: A course that covers mixed-effects models with practical applications in R.
: A comprehensive video tutorial that explains LMMs and how to apply them in R.
These resources should help you expand your knowledge and gain more practical experience with Linear Mixed Models.

children.value: Latent Growth Curve Models (LGCMs) are a statistical technique within structural equation modeling used to analyze longitudinal data by modeling the trajectory of change over time within individuals. They focus on latent variables that represent initial status (intercept) and rates of change (slope), capturing both the average growth trajectory of a population and individual deviations from that trajectory. By incorporating these latent factors, LGCMs provide a flexible framework for understanding individual differences in growth patterns and the underlying mechanisms driving change.

LGCMs are particularly useful for investigating how specific factors influence developmental processes over time. They can include time-invariant covariates (variables that do not change over time) and time-varying covariates (variables that change over time) to examine their effects on growth trajectories. This allows researchers to assess complex relationships between variables across multiple time points, such as how an intervention might impact the rate of change in an outcome variable. By accounting for measurement error and capturing unobserved heterogeneity, LGCMs enhance the analysis of longitudinal data. They enable the identification of distinct growth patterns within subgroups of a population and facilitate testing theoretical models of development. Overall, latent growth curve models offer a comprehensive approach to modeling both individual and group-level changes over time.
ü§î When to Use Latent Growth Curve Models?
You are interested in understanding how an outcome variable changes over time.
You want to model individual differences in growth trajectories.
You have repeated measures data and want to explore both group-level and individual-level changes over time.
üöÄ Getting Started with Latent Growth Curve Models
In this tutorial, you will learn how to:
Understand the structure of a latent growth curve model.
Fit an LGCM in R using a simple dataset.
Interpret the results to identify growth trajectories and individual differences.
We will use a dataset where an outcome variable is measured at four time points. LGCM will help us estimate the overall growth trajectory and individual differences in growth.
: A unique identifier for each individual.
: The outcome variable measured at time 1.
: The outcome variable measured at time 2.
: The outcome variable measured at time 3.
: The outcome variable measured at time 4.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = 1:100,
  Outcome_T1 = rnorm(100, mean = 50, sd = 10),
  Outcome_T2 = rnorm(100, mean = 52, sd = 10),
  Outcome_T3 = rnorm(100, mean = 54, sd = 10),
  Outcome_T4 = rnorm(100, mean = 56, sd = 10)
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: Fitting a Latent Growth Curve Model in R
package in R to fit an LGCM. The model will estimate both the intercept (starting point) and slope (rate of change) for the growth trajectory.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Install and load necessary library
if (!require(lavaan)) install.packages("lavaan")
library(lavaan)

# Define the LGCM model
lgcm_model <- '
  # Intercept and slope
  i =~ 1*Outcome_T1 + 1*Outcome_T2 + 1*Outcome_T3 + 1*Outcome_T4
  s =~ 0*Outcome_T1 + 1*Outcome_T2 + 2*Outcome_T3 + 3*Outcome_T4
'

# Fit the LGCM
fit <- growth(lgcm_model, data = data)

# Display the model summary
summary(fit, fit.measures = TRUE)

children.value: The intercept represents the estimated value of the outcome at the first time point, while the slope represents the rate of change over time. The model will also estimate individual-level variability in both the intercept and slope, allowing us to understand how much individuals differ from the average growth trajectory.
We can plot both the average growth trajectory and individual trajectories to visualize the overall pattern of change and the variability among individuals.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight

# Reshape data for visualization

data_long$Time <- as.numeric(sub("Outcome_T", "", data_long$Time))

# Plot individual and average growth trajectories
ggplot(data_long, aes(x = Time, y = Outcome, group = SubjectID)) +
  geom_line(alpha = 0.4) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "line", color = "blue", size = 1.2) +

children.value: # Plot individual and average growth trajectories
Latent Growth Curve Model: Individual and Average Growth Trajectories
Experiment with adding covariates to the model to explain individual differences in growth. You can also explore more complex growth patterns by adding quadratic or cubic terms to the model.

Latent Growth Curve Models are a flexible and powerful tool for modeling change over time. By estimating both the overall growth trajectory and individual differences in growth, LGCM provides insights into how populations change over time and what factors influence these changes.

children.value: Multilevel Growth Models are an extension of traditional growth models designed to account for nested data structures, such as students within schools or patients within hospitals. These models allow researchers to analyze growth at multiple levels, capturing both individual-level trajectories and group-level effects. By incorporating hierarchical data, multilevel growth models can partition variance into within-group and between-group components, providing a more accurate and nuanced understanding of developmental processes.

In longitudinal research where observations are clustered within higher-level units, multilevel growth modelss are particularly useful. They enable the examination of how individual growth trajectories are influenced not only by individual characteristics but also by group-level factors, such as classroom environments or institutional policies. This approach allows for the assessment of cross-level interactions, revealing how higher-level contexts can impact individual change over time. By accommodating the complexity of nested data, multilevel growth models offer a flexible framework for analyzing longitudinal data that respects the dependency among observations.
ü§î When to Use Multilevel Growth Models?
Consider using Multilevel Growth Models when:
You have repeated measures data nested within higher-level units (e.g., students within classrooms).
You are interested in modeling both individual growth trajectories and group-level effects.
You want to account for correlations between observations within the same group (e.g., within a classroom or hospital).
üöÄ Getting Started with Multilevel Growth Models
In this tutorial, you will learn how to:
Understand the structure of a Multilevel Growth Model.
Fit a Multilevel Growth Model in R using example data.
Interpret the results to understand individual and group-level growth trajectories.

We will use a dataset where individual growth is measured across three time points, and individuals are nested within groups. Multilevel Growth Models will help us estimate both the individual-level trajectories and the group-level effects.
: A unique identifier for each group.
: A unique identifier for each individual within the group.
: The time variable, measured at three time points.
: The outcome variable, measured repeatedly over time.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  GroupID = rep(1:10, each = 10),
  SubjectID = rep(1:100, each = 3),
  Time = rep(0:2, times = 100),
  Outcome = rnorm(300, mean = rep(seq(50, 55, length.out = 100), each = 3), sd = 5)
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: Fitting a Multilevel Growth Model in R

package in R to fit a multilevel growth model. The model will include random intercepts and random slopes at the group level, allowing us to capture both individual and group-level growth trajectories.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load necessary libraries
library(lme4)

# Fit a multilevel growth model
model <- lmer(Outcome ~ Time + (Time | GroupID/SubjectID), data = data)

# Display the model summary
summary(model)

children.value: The model estimates both the fixed effects (average growth trajectory) and the random effects (variability in growth trajectories between groups and individuals). By examining the random intercepts and slopes, we can understand how much individual and group trajectories deviate from the overall growth pattern.
We can visualize both the individual-level and group-level growth trajectories using

children.value: Multivariate Latent Growth Curve Models (LGCM), also known as parallel process latent growth curves, extend the traditional latent growth curve framework to simultaneously model the development of two or more related variables over time. By capturing the growth trajectories of multiple processes within the same model, researchers can examine how changes in one variable are associated with changes in another, providing insights into the dynamic interplay between developmental processes.

In these models, each variable has its own set of latent growth factors‚Äîtypically intercepts and slopes‚Äîthat represent initial status and rates of change. By allowing the latent factors of different variables to correlate, multivariate LGCMs assess the extent to which the trajectories of the variables are related. This approach enables the investigation of questions such as whether individuals who start higher on one variable also start higher on another, or whether the rate of change in one variable predicts the rate of change in another. Multivariate LGCMs are particularly useful in fields like psychology, education, and health sciences, where multiple developmental processes may influence each other over time. For example, researchers might use these models to explore the relationship between academic achievement and self-esteem during adolescence, assessing how changes in one domain affect changes in the other. By capturing the shared and unique aspects of growth in different variables, multivariate LGCMs offer a comprehensive view of longitudinal data.
ü§î When to Use Multivariate Latent Growth Curve Models?
You have more than one outcome variable measured repeatedly over time.
You want to understand how growth trajectories of different variables are related.
You need to examine both individual and shared dynamics in longitudinal data.
üöÄ Getting Started with Multivariate Latent Growth Curve Models
In this tutorial, we will guide you through fitting an MLGCM using R. By the end of this tutorial, you will:
Understand the concept of multivariate latent growth curve models.
Fit an MLGCM to longitudinal data with multiple outcomes.
Interpret the results and visualize shared growth trajectories.
We will create a dataset with two outcome variables, measured over three time points. These outcomes could represent different but related measures, such as cognitive performance and physical health.
: A unique identifier for each participant.
: The first outcome variable at time 1.
: The first outcome variable at time 2.
: The first outcome variable at time 3.
: The second outcome variable at time 1.
: The second outcome variable at time 2.
: The second outcome variable at time 3.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = 1:10,
  Outcome1_T1 = rnorm(10, mean = 50, sd = 10),
  Outcome1_T2 = rnorm(10, mean = 52, sd = 10),
  Outcome1_T3 = rnorm(10, mean = 55, sd = 10),
  Outcome2_T1 = rnorm(10, mean = 30, sd = 5),
  Outcome2_T2 = rnorm(10, mean = 32, sd = 5),
  Outcome2_T3 = rnorm(10, mean = 34, sd = 5)
)

# View the first few rows of the dataset
head(data)

children.value: # View the first few rows of the dataset
Fitting a Multivariate Latent Growth Curve Model in R
package to fit an MLGCM, where we estimate the growth trajectories for both Outcome1 and Outcome2.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Install and load necessary library
if (!require(lavaan)) install.packages("lavaan")
library(lavaan)

# Define the multivariate latent growth curve model
mlgcm_model <- '
  # Growth factors for Outcome 1
  i1 =~ 1*Outcome1_T1 + 1*Outcome1_T2 + 1*Outcome1_T3
  s1 =~ 0*Outcome1_T1 + 1*Outcome1_T2 + 2*Outcome1_T3

  # Growth factors for Outcome 2
  i2 =~ 1*Outcome2_T1 + 1*Outcome2_T2 + 1*Outcome2_T3
  s2 =~ 0*Outcome2_T1 + 1*Outcome2_T2 + 2*Outcome2_T3

  # Covariances between intercepts and slopes
  i1 ~~ i2
  s1 ~~ s2
'

# Fit the MLGCM
fit <- sem(mlgcm_model, data = data)

# Display the model summary
summary(fit, fit.measures = TRUE)

children.value: # Define the multivariate latent growth curve model

The model will provide estimates for the intercepts and slopes for both outcome variables, along with the covariances between these growth factors. These covariances tell us how the growth in one outcome is related to growth in the other.
Visualizing the individual and shared trajectories can provide a clearer understanding of the relationships between the outcomes.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 for visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Reshape the data for visualization
data_long <- reshape2::melt(data, id.vars = "SubjectID", variable.name = "Outcome", value.name = "Score")
data_long$Time <- as.numeric(sub(".*_(T)", "", data_long$Outcome))
data_long$Variable <- sub("_T.*", "", data_long$Outcome)

# Plot the trajectories
ggplot(data_long, aes(x = Time, y = Score, color = Variable)) +
  geom_line(aes(group = interaction(SubjectID, Variable))) +
  facet_wrap(~SubjectID) +
  labs(
    title = "Growth Trajectories for Two Outcomes",
    x = "Time",
    y = "Score"
  )

children.value: Experiment with adding more outcomes or covariates to see how they influence the shared growth trajectories. You can also explore different correlation structures between the growth factors.

Multivariate latent growth curve models offer a flexible and powerful way to understand how multiple outcomes change over time and how their growth trajectories are related. This method is ideal when you want to explore shared dynamics in longitudinal data.

children.value: Piecewise Latent Growth Curve Models (LGCM) are an extension of latent growth curve modeling that allow researchers to model developmental trajectories that change direction or rate at specific points in time. These models are particularly useful when the process under study is hypothesized to have different phases, each with its own distinct pattern of change. By dividing the overall time span into segments and specifying ‚Äúknots‚Äù or breakpoints, piecewise models estimate separate growth parameters‚Äîsuch as intercepts and slopes‚Äîfor each segment, providing a more accurate representation of complex longitudinal data.

In a piecewise LGCM, the trajectory is modeled as a series of connected linear segments, with each segment capturing the growth rate within a specific time interval. This approach allows for the modeling of non-linear change in a linear framework by connecting these linear pieces at the specified breakpoints. Researchers can examine how growth rates differ before and after events like interventions, policy changes, or developmental milestones, testing hypotheses about shifts in the trajectory. By accommodating changes in growth patterns over time, these models offer a flexible and powerful tool for analyzing longitudinal data where the assumption of a single, continuous growth process is inadequate. Piecewise LGCMs enhance the ability to detect and interpret shifts in developmental trajectories, providing deeper insights into processes that exhibit different phases of change.
ü§î When to Use Piecewise Growth Models?
Piecewise Growth Models are useful when:
You believe that growth trajectories may change at specific points in time, such as before and after an intervention.
You want to estimate separate growth rates for different time intervals.
You have repeated measures data with potential shifts in the rate of change over time.
üöÄ Getting Started with Piecewise Growth Models
Understand how to set up and fit a piecewise growth model.
Fit a PGM in R using a simple dataset with two growth segments.
Interpret the results to understand how the growth rates change over time.

We will generate a dataset where an outcome variable is measured at six time points. The first three time points will represent a pre-intervention phase, and the last three will represent a post-intervention phase. The goal is to model different growth rates before and after the intervention.
: A unique identifier for each individual.
: The outcome variable measured over time.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = rep(1:50, each = 6),
  Time = rep(1:6, times = 50),
  Outcome = c(rep(rnorm(50, mean = 50, sd = 5), 3), rep(rnorm(50, mean = 60, sd = 5), 3))
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: Fitting a Piecewise Growth Model in R
package in R to fit a piecewise growth model. We will define two segments: one for time points 1-3 (pre-intervention) and one for time points 4-6 (post-intervention).

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load necessary libraries
library(lme4)

# Define time segments: 1-3 (pre) and 4-6 (post)
data$Pre_Post <- ifelse(data$Time <= 3, 0, 1)

# Fit a piecewise growth model
model <- lmer(Outcome ~ Time + Pre_Post + Time:Pre_Post + (1 | SubjectID), data = data)

# Display model summary
summary(model)

children.value: The model estimates separate growth rates for the pre-intervention and post-intervention periods. The interaction term
tells us how the growth rate changes after the intervention.
We can plot the growth trajectories to visualize how the rate of change differs before and after the intervention.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 for visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Plot individual growth trajectories and group means
ggplot(data, aes(x = Time, y = Outcome, group = SubjectID)) +
  geom_line(alpha = 0.4) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "line", color = "blue", size = 1.2) +
  labs(
    title = "Piecewise Growth Model: Pre- and Post-Intervention Trajectories",
    x = "Time (Years)",
    y = "Outcome"
  )

children.value: # Plot individual growth trajectories and group means
Piecewise Growth Model: Pre- and Post-Intervention Trajectories

Experiment with changing the time point where the intervention occurs or adding more time segments to model more complex growth patterns. You can also explore adding covariates to explain variability in the growth rates between individuals.

Piecewise Growth Models are a powerful tool for modeling growth trajectories that change at specific points in time. By breaking the growth trajectory into segments, you can capture shifts in the rate of change, making these models particularly useful when studying interventions or life events.

children.value: Growth Mixture Models (GMMs) are an extension of latent growth curve models that allow researchers to identify distinct subgroups, or classes, within a population that share similar developmental trajectories over time. Unlike traditional growth models that assume a single homogeneous population, GMMs acknowledge that individuals may follow different patterns of change. By integrating latent class analysis into the growth modeling framework, GMMs simultaneously estimate growth parameters for each class and assign individuals to these latent classes based on their observed data.

In GMMs, each latent class has its own set of growth parameters‚Äîsuch as intercepts and slopes‚Äîcapturing unique growth trajectories for different subgroups within the data. This approach enables the exploration of heterogeneity in developmental processes, revealing unobserved subpopulations that may differ in their initial status and rates of change. GMMs are particularly useful when there is reason to believe that the population is not uniform in its development, such as when studying diverse responses to an intervention or varying progression of a condition.

By uncovering distinct growth patterns and estimating the proportion of the population belonging to each class, growth mixture models provide a powerful tool for understanding complex longitudinal data. They allow for the examination of how individual characteristics or covariates influence class membership and growth trajectories within classes. This facilitates more tailored interpretations and interventions by recognizing and modeling the diversity inherent in developmental processes.
ü§î When to Use Growth Mixture Models?
You want to identify distinct latent classes with different growth patterns, but also allow for individual variability within classes.
You have repeated measures data and expect both between-class and within-class heterogeneity.
You are interested in both the group-level and individual-level differences in growth trajectories.
üöÄ Getting Started with Growth Mixture Models
In this tutorial, you will learn how to:
Understand the structure of a Growth Mixture Model (GMM).
Fit a GMM in R using example data.
Interpret the results to identify latent classes and individual growth trajectories.

We will generate a dataset where an outcome variable is measured at three time points for several individuals. GMM will help us identify distinct latent classes based on growth trajectories, while accounting for individual-level variation within each class.
: A unique identifier for each participant.
: The outcome variable measured at time 1.
: The outcome variable measured at time 2.
: The outcome variable measured at time 3.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = 1:100,
  Outcome_T1 = c(rnorm(50, mean = 50, sd = 10), rnorm(50, mean = 70, sd = 10)),
  Outcome_T2 = c(rnorm(50, mean = 52, sd = 10), rnorm(50, mean = 72, sd = 10)),
  Outcome_T3 = c(rnorm(50, mean = 55, sd = 10), rnorm(50, mean = 75, sd = 10))
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: Fitting a Growth Mixture Model in R
package to fit a GMM. This model will estimate the growth trajectories for distinct latent classes while also modeling the individual variation within each class.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Install and load necessary library
if (!require(lcmm)) install.packages("lcmm")
library(lcmm)

# Fit a GMM model with 2 latent classes
gmm_model <- hlme(fixed = Outcome_T1 + Outcome_T2 + Outcome_T3 ~ 1, random = ~ 1, subject = "SubjectID", ng = 2, data = data)

# Display the model summary
summary(gmm_model)

children.value: # Fit a GMM model with 2 latent classes

The model will estimate both the class-specific growth trajectories and the individual-level variability within each class. Based on the class membership probabilities, we can identify which individuals are most likely to belong to each latent class and observe their individual growth patterns.
Visualizing the Latent Classes and Individual Growth Trajectories
We can visualize both the mean growth trajectories for each latent class and the individual trajectories within each class.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 for visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Plot the mean growth trajectories for each latent class
class_assignments <- predict(gmm_model, class = TRUE)
data$class <- factor(class_assignments$class)

ggplot(data, aes(x = factor(c(1, 2, 3)), y = Outcome_T1, group = SubjectID, color = class)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = Outcome_T1)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = Outcome_T2)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = Outcome_T3)) +
  labs(
    title = "Growth Mixture Model: Individual and Latent Class Trajectories",
    x = "Time",
    y = "Outcome",
    color = "Latent Class"
  )

children.value: # Plot the mean growth trajectories for each latent class
Growth Mixture Model: Individual and Latent Class Trajectories

Experiment with changing the number of latent classes or adding covariates to the model. Explore how individual-level variability within each class changes the interpretation of the growth trajectories.

Growth Mixture Models offer a flexible way to model both group-level and individual-level differences in growth trajectories. By allowing for individual variability within latent classes, GMM provides more nuanced insights into how individuals change over time within distinct subgroups.

children.value: Latent Class Growth Analysis (LCGA) is a statistical technique that extends traditional growth modeling by identifying distinct subgroups, or latent classes, within a population that share similar developmental trajectories over time. Unlike standard growth models that assume a single homogeneous population, LCGA acknowledges that the population may consist of multiple unobserved groups, each following a unique pattern of change. By partitioning individuals into these latent classes, LCGA allows researchers to explore heterogeneity in growth patterns and understand how different subgroups evolve over time.

In LCGA, within-class variability in growth parameters is constrained to zero, meaning that all individuals within a latent class are assumed to have the same growth trajectory. This simplification distinguishes LCGA from Growth Mixture Models (GMM), which allow for individual variability within classes. By fixing within-class variances, LCGA focuses on capturing the major differences between classes, making it a useful tool when the primary interest is in identifying distinct developmental pathways rather than individual differences within those pathways.

LCGA is particularly valuable in fields such as psychology, education, and public health, where understanding the existence of qualitatively different growth patterns can inform theory and practice. For example, researchers might use LCGA to identify subgroups of patients who respond differently to a treatment over time or to uncover distinct trajectories of academic achievement among students. By revealing the presence of multiple latent classes with unique growth patterns, LCGA provides a framework for tailoring interventions and advancing knowledge about the diversity of developmental processes.
ü§î When to Use Latent Class Growth Analysis?
You believe there are unobserved subgroups in the population with distinct growth trajectories.
You want to identify and describe these latent classes based on their growth patterns.
You have repeated measures data and wish to model heterogeneity in growth over time.
üöÄ Getting Started with Latent Class Growth Analysis
Understand how LCGA identifies latent subgroups based on growth trajectories.
Fit an LCGA model in R using example data.
Interpret the results to identify distinct latent classes.
We will use a dataset where an outcome variable is measured at three time points. LCGA will help us identify distinct latent classes based on how individuals' outcomes change over time.
: A unique identifier for each individual.
: The outcome variable measured at time 1.
: The outcome variable measured at time 2.
: The outcome variable measured at time 3.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Generate a simple dataset
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  SubjectID = 1:100,
  Outcome_T1 = c(rnorm(50, mean = 50, sd = 10), rnorm(50, mean = 70, sd = 10)),
  Outcome_T2 = c(rnorm(50, mean = 52, sd = 10), rnorm(50, mean = 72, sd = 10)),
  Outcome_T3 = c(rnorm(50, mean = 55, sd = 10), rnorm(50, mean = 75, sd = 10))
)

# View the first few rows
head(data)

children.value: Fitting a Latent Class Growth Analysis Model in R
package in R to fit an LCGA model, where we estimate growth trajectories for distinct latent classes.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Install and load necessary library
if (!require(lcmm)) install.packages("lcmm")
library(lcmm)

# Fit an LCGA model with 2 latent classes
lcga_model <- hlme(fixed = Outcome_T1 + Outcome_T2 + Outcome_T3 ~ 1, subject = "SubjectID", ng = 2, data = data)

# Display the model summary
summary(lcga_model)

children.value: # Fit an LCGA model with 2 latent classes

The model will estimate the growth trajectories for each latent class. Based on the class membership probabilities, we can identify which individuals are most likely to belong to each class. The differences in the growth patterns between classes will reveal the heterogeneity in the population.
Visualizing the growth trajectories for each latent class can help us understand how the classes differ over time.

props.className: language-r shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
# Load ggplot2 for visualization
library(ggplot2)

# Plot the mean growth trajectories for each latent class
class_assignments <- predict(lcga_model, class = TRUE)
data$class <- factor(class_assignments$class)

ggplot(data, aes(x = factor(c(1, 2, 3)), y = Outcome_T1, group = SubjectID, color = class)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = Outcome_T1)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = Outcome_T2)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = Outcome_T3)) +
  labs(
    title = "Latent Class Growth Trajectories",
    x = "Time",
    y = "Outcome",
    color = "Latent Class"
  )

children.value: # Plot the mean growth trajectories for each latent class
Try modifying the number of latent classes or adding covariates to the model. Explore how different numbers of classes change the interpretation of the growth trajectories.

Latent Class Growth Analysis is a powerful tool for uncovering hidden subgroups within a population based on their growth patterns. By identifying distinct latent classes, you can gain insights into heterogeneity that may be masked when looking at the population as a whole.
üîó Further Resources for Learning About Latent Class Growth Analysis

by Timothy Church: A helpful guide that covers LCGA and other related methods.

: A guide on how to fit LCGA models using R.
